channel.title: Booting?
channel.description:
I have a 40 gb hdd (Ubuntu 9.04, master) and a 120gb hdd (windows 7, slave) how can I make it so I can choose what it boots into at startup instead of just going straight into linux.
Thanks ahead of time.

item.title: Booting?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Unfortunately you may have to use a bit of trial and error.

However, one thing you can do is press c at the grub menu to enter the console and run geometry (hd0) and geometry (hd1) - this will show you how many partitions are on each drive, at which point you can eliminate the ones you know about.

If you did a standard Windows install on the Windows drive, it will either contain one partition in the case of XP or below, or two (one really tiny one) in the case of Vista/7. Unless it’s an OEM install, in which case it might be different.

Basically, you just need to try though, I think. You won’t break anything by putting the wrong value other than the Windows option, so you’ll still be able to boot into Ubuntu to fix it if you’re wrong.

In case it isn’t obvious, the number refers to the drive and partition that your Windows bootloader is on. It will almost certainly be (hd1,0) or (hd1,1), but it may not. Try both first.

And yeah you’re right about the path, oops.

EDIT: Also you can try running the commands I listed above from that console, rather than editing the file, to save rebooting and editing the file a bunch. Once you get it right (ie Windows boots) then go and edit the file.

item.title: Booting?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

On newer versions of Ubuntu (and therefore newer versions of Grub) this happens automatically, but it may not have done on 9.04.

Edit /boot/menu.lst and add

title Windows
rootnoverify(hd1,0)
makeactive
chainloader +1

Usually this is already in the file, but commented out.

I took a wild stab in the dark at the (hd1,0). If this doesn’t work for you, you will need to find out what grub thinks the Windows boot partition is and replace it here.
